text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- British Foreign Office Minister Derek Fatchett affirms need to support Jordan politically and economically.
- Professional unions to meet on June 6 over government proposals for bonus payments.
- Jordan to sign partnership agreement with Europe next month.
- Parliamentary opposition sources say opposition members discussed resigning in protest at government passing provisional laws while parliament not sitting, but decided against it.
- Government source says World Bank to sign loan agreement with Jordan worth $60 million at the start of next month to fund social support programme.
- Head of parliamentary committee studying finances of state-owned Royal Jordanian airlines raps committee raporteur as "irresponsible" for announcing committee's report.
- King attends army live fire exercises and celebrations marking anniversary of first armoured regiment.
- Journalists present suggestions over press law amendments to Prime Minister Abdul-Salam al-Majali.
- Head of anti-corruption office says corruption in Jordan is snowballing.
- Money-changer's stall raided in Amman. Thieves make off with 13,285 dinars ($18,800).
- Planning Minister Rima Khalaf says the government agrees to pay 50 percent of salary of poor people employed by private sector for first six months of employment.
- Amman bourse closes at highest level since late 1995.
- Jordan eager to remove trade obstacles, Prime Minister Abdul-Salam al-Majali says.
